bestBHT.bht: To seek justification before God, one must approach with humility, not self-righteousness. The Pharisee's exaltation led to his failure in obtaining God's justification. In contrast, the humble publican was exalted and received the answer to his prayer, finding justification. Only those who are self-emptied and recognize their need for God's grace receive the grace which bringeth salvation. Righteousness is obtained through the forgiveness of sins, and God is pleased with a humble demeanor, while pride and self-trust are abhorred.

Henry Alford: Therefore he who would seek justification before God must seek it by humility and not by self-righteousness.
Every one that exalteth himself has been illustrated in the demeanour of the Pharisee—shall be abased, in his failure to obtain justification from God.
He that humbleth himself, in that of the Publican—shall be exalted, in his obtaining the answer to his prayer, which was this justification.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: To be self-emptied, or, 'poor in spirit,' is the fundamental and indispensable preparation for the reception of the 'grace which bringeth salvation'".

Wherever this exists, the 'mourning' for it which precedes 'comfort' and the earnest 'hungerings and thirstings after righteousness' which are rewarded by the 'fulness' of it, will, as we see here, be surely found".
Such, therefore, and such only, are the justified ones".
Albert Barnes: God judges of this differently from people.
Justified - Accepted or approved of God.
John Calvin: For it is not said that the publican was justified, because he suddenly acquired some new quality, but that he obtained grace, because his guilt was blotted out, and his sins were washed away.
Hence it follows, that righteousness consists in the forgiveness of sins.
God will not be pacified towards us, unless we distrust works, and pray that we may be freely reconciled.
Philip Schaff: The publican’s prayer was answered, that God was merciful to this sinner, and this is precisely what is meant by justification, namely, God’s forgiving our sins and accepting us as righteous.
Our Lord is very forbearing in His judgment on the Pharisee. But He certainly means that the latter was not justified, for he had not asked for this.

The Pharisee, though previously a more moral man than the other, failed to be justified, not because he was more moral, but because he was self-righteous; the publican, the worse man of the two, was justified, not because he was worse, but because he was a humble penitent.
Archibald T. Robertson: This man (ουτος). This despised publican referred to contemptuously in verse Luke 18:11 as 'this' (ουτος) publican."
Rather than the other (παρ' εκεινον). In comparison with (placed beside) that one. A neat Greek idiom after the perfect passive participle δεδικαιομενος.
For (οτ). This moral maxim Christ had already used in Luke 14:11. Plummer pertinently asks: 'Why is it assumed that Jesus did not repeat his sayings?'
John Gill: justified from all his sins, and accepted by him, when the other was abhorred and neglected.
an humble demeanour being well pleasing and acceptable to him, when pride, and arrogance, boasting of, and trusting in a man's own righteousness, are abhorred by him.
every one that exalteth himself, shall be abased, and he that humbleth himself, shall be exalted.
John Wesley: This man went down — From the hill on which the temple stood, justified rather than the other - That is, and not the other.

bhtAttempts.bht: Therefore, in order to seek justification before God, one must approach with humility rather than self-righteousness. Those who exalt themselves will fail to obtain justification, while those who humble themselves, as illustrated by the publican, will be exalted and receive the answer to their prayers. Humility and a recognition of one's need for God's grace are fundamental for receiving the grace which bringeth salvation. This humble posture leads to mourning for one's sin and a deep hunger and thirst for righteousness, which are rewarded by the fullness of God's justification. Only those who embrace this self-emptying and humble disposition are the justified ones. The publican in the story is contrasted with the Pharisee, who relied on his self-righteousness. Though the Pharisee was more moral, he failed to be justified because of his self-righteousness. On the other hand, despite being a worse man, the publican was justified because of his humble repentance. Ultimately, righteousness consists in the forgiveness of sins, and God is pleased by humble demeanor while abhorring pride and self-trust.

To seek justification before God, one must approach with humility, not self-righteousness. The Pharisee's exaltation led to his failure in obtaining God's justification. In contrast, the humble publican was exalted and received the answer to his prayer, finding justification. Only those who are self-emptied and recognize their need for God's grace receive the grace which bringeth salvation. Righteousness is obtained through the forgiveness of sins, and God is pleased with a humble demeanor, while pride and self-trust are abhorred.

To seek justification from God, one must approach with humility. The Pharisee exemplifies self-exaltation, leading to his failure in obtaining justification. On the other hand, the humble publican is exalted and finds justification through his prayer. True justification requires self-emptying and recognizing our need for God's grace. It is the forgiveness of sins that constitutes righteousness. God favors those who approach in humility, while pride and self-reliance are detested.

To obtain justification from God, one must seek it through humility rather than self-righteousness. The Pharisee's exaltation resulted in his failure to receive justification from God, whereas the humble publican's prayer led to his exaltation and justification. True justification requires self-emptying, acknowledging our need for God's grace and forgiveness. This humility precedes mourning for sin, hungering and thirsting after righteousness, and ultimately receiving the fullness of God's justification. Only those who embrace this humble disposition are considered justified. God is pleased with humility and despises pride and self-trust.

To obtain justification, one must seek it through humility, rather than self-righteousness. The Pharisee's exaltation led to failure, while the humble publican's prayer resulted in exaltation and justification. This humility is essential for receiving the grace which bringeth salvation. It involves mourning for sin, seeking after righteousness, and ultimately being fully justified by God. This humble posture is pleasing to God, while pride and self-reliance are abhorred.
